At Thu, 17 Jun 2010 12:27:52 -0700,
steve@... wrote:
> 
> you want =
to examine the HTTP header Content-Type contained
> _within_ the WARC recor=
d, rather than the WARC header
> Content-Type.
> 
> the crawl-report report=
s HTTP header Content-Type(s). WARC files
> also contain WARC header Conten=
t-Type(s) as eluded to by Erik.
> there will be a request, response, and me=
tadata WARC record
> header for each target-URI, which also contain their o=
wn
> Content-Type field.
> 
> e.g. for "WARC-Target-URI: http://www.archive=
.org/" the
> following "Content-Type" entries will be reported in a WARC
> =
record (with other selected fields):
>
> [=E2=80=A6]
>
> org.archive.io.Arc=
hiveRecordHeader.getMimetype() should report
> the mimetype you're interest=
ed in.
> 
> hope that helps.

Hi Steve, all,

Thanks for the very clear exp=
lanation of the issue, Steve.

I just had another look at this because I wi=
ll need to be parsing WARC
records myself soon.

I tested getMimetype - it =
seems to return the WARC Content-type rather
than the body Content-Type.

T=
he WARCIndexer tool bundled with the open source wayback does,
however, ext=
ract the MIME type from the actual response. It does this
by parsing the HT=
TP headers itself. Here is a good starting place to
see how to extract the =
HTTP headers from the WARC record:

  https://archive-access.svn.sourceforg=
e.net/svnroot/archive-access/trunk/archive-access/projects/wayback/wayback-=
core/src/main/java/org/archive/wayback/resourcestore/indexer/WARCRecordToSe=
archResultAdapter.java

Hopefully the WARC/ARC API will be cleaned up soon;=
 it is strange to
have the same method (getMimetype) with completely differ=
ent
semantics.

If you are only using WARCs, an alternative might be to use=
 the WARC
tools here:

  http://law.dsi.unimi.it/index.php?option=3Dcom_con=
tent&task=3Dview&id=3D35&Itemid=3D42

Which contains code for parsing the H=
TTP response itself.

best, Erik
